title: The Causal Effect of Public Policy and Income on Child Health and Human Capital
descriptions:
**Grant Proposal Abstract:**

The "missing middle" years between early infancy and adulthood remain a significant knowledge gap in understanding the formation of human capital. Recent studies have shown that early shocks and interventions can have lasting effects on adult health and wages, but little is known about the intermediate years. This project aims to bridge this gap by analyzing the causal effects of various early childhood shocks on child development and human capital formation. Using high-quality administrative data from Spain, covering the past 35 years, the study will investigate the impacts of five distinct shocks on household material resources, parental time, medical treatments, family planning services, and aggregate demand shocks. By employing cutting-edge econometric techniques and large sample sizes, this research will provide precise estimates of the effects of these shocks on health and cognitive development at ages 0-15, as measured through various data sources, including hospital records, school grades, and standardized test scores. Additionally, the study will explore the underlying channels through which these shocks influence child outcomes, including family size, parental time use, labor market outcomes, and expenditure patterns. The findings of this research will have direct policy implications for improving young children's future outcomes and informing cost-effective interventions.

**Description:**

A recent literature in economics on the “fetal origins hypothesis” has documented that a range of early (prenatal and postnatal) shocks and interventions can have substantial effects on long-term human capital formation (e.g. adult health, wages). However, we still know little about the years in between early infancy and adulthood, referred to as the “missing middle”. How do early shocks affect health and human capital formation during childhood? How do the effects of different types of interventions, or shocks at different ages, compare? What are the most cost-effective ways of improving young children’s future outcomes? I aim to fill this gap in the literature by taking advantage of a range of natural experiments in a country, Spain, for which high quality administrative data are available for the past 35 years. State of the art econometric techniques, combined with large sample sizes, will allow me to evaluate credibly and precisely the causal effects of a number of different public policies and shocks on child development. I will consider five different “shocks” in early childhood (at different ages), affecting: i) Household material resources (an unconditional mother’s allowance); ii) Parental time (subsidized paternity leave); iii) Medical treatments around birth (elective delivery); iv) The availability of family planning services (access to abortion); and v) Aggregate demand shocks to different sectors of the economy. I will evaluate their impact on health and cognitive development at ages 0-15, as measured in hospital and primary health care records, school grades, and standardized test scores, among other data sources. I will also study the potential channels linking treatments to child outcomes, including family size (fertility), parental time use and labor market outcomes, expenditure patterns, etc. My results will help us understand how shocks in early life can have long-term effects on human capital, with direct policy implications.
